div.p: In accordance with your request I here with detail all the facts relating to the killing of a guerilla named John Pride

You were riding at the hind of your Regiment. Henry Warren Srgt Mayor of the 9th Tenn Cavalry & myself at your side when we were nearly abreast of a hill thickly covered with timber we were fired upon by a forty of men who had concealed timberlines then we immediately rallid & some of our men were about to fire when you commanded them not to do as as you insisted they were our own men. about twenty of us found them as you were hiltn mounted then altunaltun you was able to keep in advance we fussed the guerillas closely & Pride was forced to quit his horse & endeavored to escape in first you ordered him to surrender which he did & you funnled one or two men from shooting at him by hitting them till he had surrendered

When however you advanced toward him he deemed to think as you was at that time in advance of us that by killing you he could yet effect his escape he fired at you (this was after his surrender) once or twice, I think I can safely say twice you then took deliberate aim & shot him you shot you were very close together but I am positive that you fired but once and only after he had fired at you. His brother who was Gene Willams orderly stated publicly that you was justifiable & acted on the hardest principal of self defense you will probably remember that Capt James Bald was shot by a Rebel Soldier at Morristown after he (the Rebel) had surrendered

The forty that fired on us did us in a dastardly & cowardly manner were guerillas & bush whackers & not enlisted to the wrongs of civilizezd maybe they had allowed two full companies of our troops to pass them & evidently desired to pick off some of our officers
W Bayless Lots Adj. 9 th Ten Com
